Climate change will increase the variability of global crop yields, making it more difficult to achieve food security. We show that the variability of maize yields will increase substantially in the world’s major maize-producing and -exporting countries under 2 °C and 4 °C of global warming. This increase in variability will increase the probability that these countries will have simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year. Our results highlight the need for investments in breeding maize varieties that are more heat tolerant.

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is important for understanding the causes and consequences of biodiversity. However, the extent to which different species partition food resources is largely unknown because of the difficulty of identifying species-level taxa in the field. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify the diet breadth, composition, and overlap of seven abundant large mammal species in semiarid African savanna. Our results suggest that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in large mammal assemblages, and that the diversity of large mammal species may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. Our findings have implications for understanding the causes and consequences of biodiversity in a world of limited resources.

The ability to increase the amount of resources available to the mother is one of the most important adaptations that has allowed for the success of mammals. Here, we show that the ability to provide resources to the mother, either through domestication or allomaternal care, is associated with increased reproductive output. This increase is due to an increase in the amount of resources available to the mother rather than an increase in the number of litters produced. This result suggests that the limiting factor on reproductive output in placental mammals is the metabolic power of the mother.

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that affects the autonomic nervous system, the basal ganglia, and the cerebellum. The disease is characterized by the presence of α-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in affected neurons. In this study, we show that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765, which was well tolerated in a phase II clinical trial in patients with epilepsy, is able to reduce the load of α-syn aggregates in a mouse model of MSA. This reduction was associated with a reduction of truncated α-syn, which is a major contributor to neurotoxicity in MSA. This resistance is mediated by the activation of sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1/stearoyl-CoA desaturase-1-dependent lipogenesis, which protects cancer cells from oxidative stress and ferroptotic death. This suggests that the adult immune system is able to compensate for the loss of CTLA-4.

The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is a topic of great interest to evolutionary psychologists. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. We found that larger populations did not enhance CCE, but that the size of the population did affect the variation in plane performance and the quality of the planes that participants could access. Our results suggest that it may be only under certain specific conditions that larger population sizes enhance CCE. Our findings have implications for the evolution of technology and the evolution of culture.

The APOE gene is the strongest genetic risk factor influencing late-onset Alzheimer’s disease (AD) risk. APOE isoform is also associated with differential risk of AD. Here, we report a novel role for APOE in regulating the rate of astrocytic phagocytosis of synapses, which is highly dependent on APOE isoform. We also found that APOE alleles are associated with differential levels of C1q accumulation in the brain, which may represent the accumulation of senescent synapses with enhanced vulnerability to complement-mediated neurodegeneration. These studies reveal a novel allele-dependent role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. They also suggest the hypothesis that AD susceptibility of APOE4 may originate in part from defective phagocytic capacity of astrocytes which accelerates the rate of accumulation of C1q-coated senescent synapses, enhancing synaptic vulnerability to classical-complement-cascade mediated neurodegeneration. These studies provide a molecular mechanism for the differential risk of APOE alleles in AD. They also suggest a potential therapeutic target for AD. (Show more)

Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States. Although the effects of marijuana on the brain are well known, the effects of chronic marijuana use on the brain are not. Here, we show that chronic marijuana use is associated with reduced brain reactivity to methylphenidate, a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine (DA) levels in the brain. This reduced reactivity is associated with increased stress reactivity and irritability, which are common features of marijuana abuse. These findings have implications for understanding the effects of marijuana on the brain and for the development of effective treatments for marijuana abuse.

Language is the only known cognitive skill that evolved in isolation from other animals. This has led to the hypothesis that language is a uniquely human ability. Here we show that a class of deep learning models, which are trained on a wide range of unrelated tasks, can accurately predict the neural responses to sentences in the absence of any training data on language. This suggests that the language comprehension mechanisms in the human brain are shaped by predictive processing across a wide range of tasks. Our results provide computational evidence for the uniqueness of language in the human mind.

This argument is based on a classic psychological experiment published 45 years ago. Despite its critical design flaws, the experiment is still widely cited. Here, we discuss the flaws of the experiment and how they undermine its conclusion.

Leprosy is a disease that has been studied for centuries, and the cause of it has been debated for even longer. In this study, we sequenced the genome of a patient with lepromatous leprosy and compared it with that of the causative agent of Hansen's disease, M. leprae. Our results suggest that the two pathogens have retained many of their ancestral functions and are still capable of causing disease.

The dynamics of entanglement in quantum many-body systems is a fundamental question of quantum information theory and statistical mechanics. In this work, we provide a complete description of the entanglement dynamics in the space–time scaling limit for a paradigmatic model, the Heisenberg chain. Our result is based on the integrability of the model, which allows us to compute the entanglement entropy of the steady state and its excitations. We check our result for the paradigmatic case of the Heisenberg chain and show that it is consistent with numerical data. Our work provides a general framework for the entanglement dynamics in interacting quantum systems. It also opens the way to the study of the dynamics of other fundamental quantities of quantum many-body systems, such as the correlation length. This is a fundamental step toward the understanding of the dynamics of quantum matter.

The Black Death, caused by Yersinia pestis, was the most devastating epidemic in human history. The disease spread rapidly through Europe, killing millions of people. The vector of the disease is still debated, with the most common hypothesis being that rats were the main transmission pathway. Here, we present a model for plague transmission by human ectoparasites, which was the most common vector in Europe during the Second Pandemic (14–19th centuries). Our results show that this model fits mortality curves better than models for rodent transmission. This suggests that human ectoparasites were the primary vectors of plague during the Black Death, ultimately challenging the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. Our results also suggest that the Black Death was not the first epidemic caused by Y. pestis, but rather the last in a series of recurrent epidemics. This has important implications for our understanding of the history of plague and the role of vector control in the control of infectious diseases.

Actin depolymerizing factor (ADF) is a protein that is involved in the disassembly of actin filaments. The ribosome is a complex molecular machine that is responsible for translating messenger RNA (mRNA) into a protein. The enzymatic incorporation of mRNA modifications has many potential outcomes, including changing mRNA stability, protein recruitment, and translation. In this study, we show that the modification pseudouridine (Ψ) can have a modest impact on translation by changing the rate of protein synthesis. The evolution of larger body sizes in aquatic mammals is a key feature of the evolution of aquatic life. Here, we show that the evolution of an aquatic lifestyle is driving the evolution of larger body sizes in four of the five extant aquatic mammal lineages. We show that the evolution of larger body sizes is driven by the strict energetic constraints of the aquatic medium.

We show that mouse airway cells infected with rhinovirus exhibit a striking enrichment in expression of antiviral defense response genes at 37 °C relative to 33 °C, which correlates with higher expression levels of type I and type III IFN genes and ISGs at 37 °C. These findings demonstrate that in mouse airway cells, rhinovirus replicates preferentially at nasal cavity temperature due, in part, to a less efficient antiviral defense response of infected cells at cool temperature. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in white-tailed deer, providing evidence that the virus is circulating in free-living animals. Our findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic and the need for a robust and proactive “One Health” approach to obtain enhanced understanding of the ecology, molecular evolution, and dissemination of SARS-CoV-2. The amyloid-β (Aβ) peptide is the most toxic component of the Alzheimer’s disease (AD) brain, but its role in the initiation of the disease is still debated. Here, we show that neurons are the major source of Aβ in the brain, and that Aβ-burdened neurons are the primary source of inflammation in the brain. This finding has important implications for the understanding of the AD pathogenesis, since it suggests that the intraneuronal accumulation of Aβ may be the primary cause of the neuroinflammation, which is a key event in the development of AD.

The domestic chicken is one of the most widespread and important domesticated species in the world. However, the earliest evidence for economic exploitation of chickens is still unknown. Here we present the results of a faunal analysis of the Hellenistic site of Maresha, Israel, which shows that the exploitation of chickens was widespread and economically important in the Southern Levant during the fourth–second centuries B.C.E. This early evidence for the economic use of chickens in the region is crucial for understanding the spread of this species in the Mediterranean world.

The folding of a protein is a complex process, and the details are important for understanding the role of the protein in the cell. This study adds to the growing list of proteins that fold through distinct native-like intermediates in distinct pathways. The study also provides a method for studying folding that is not limited by the size of the protein.

The accumulation of dinucleoside tetraphosphates (Np4) in response to stress has been shown to be a mechanism for regulating gene expression in bacteria. However, the cellular conditions that lead to the production of these molecules are not well understood. Here, we show that the decapping enzyme responsible for removing the cap structure from Np4-capped RNAs is also the predominant enzyme responsible for the deprotection of other Np4-capped RNAs. This enzyme, which is normally inactive under conditions of stress, is activated by the accumulation of Np4, and its activity is required for the rapid degradation of Np4-capped RNAs. Our findings have implications for our understanding of the role of Np4 in stress response and gene expression. (Show more)

Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with high mortality. The immune system is the main target of sepsis, and the main cause of death is the development of sepsis-induced immunosuppression. In this study, we demonstrated that citrulline, a nonessential amino acid, is an effective strategy to restore the immune system in sepsis. This study provides evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis.

The biomass of the biosphere is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined, and that the biomass of animals is an order of magnitude higher than that of plants. We also show that the biomass pyramid of the global marine ecosystem contains more consumers than producers, thus increasing the scope of previous observations on inverse food pyramids. Finally, we highlight the historical impact of humanity on the global biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Our results provide a global view of the biomass of the biosphere and its distribution among the kingdoms of life. They are essential for understanding the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. They also provide a global perspective on the impact of humans on the biosphere.

Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a phenomenon in nature and in physics, where a system is in a critical state and self-regulates its activity. SOC systems are characterized by a power-law distribution of activity levels, a power-law distribution of relaxation times, and a power-law distribution of correlation times. In this paper, we report on our discovery of a tropical model with self-organized criticality (SOC) behavior. Our model is continuous, in contrast to all known models of SOC, and is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model, the first and archetypical model of SOC. We describe how our model is related to pattern formation and proportional growth phenomena and discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim in this context is to present an idealized tropical toy model (cf. Turing reaction-diffusion model), requiring further investigation.

The common human bleeding disorder, von Willebrand disease, is caused by mutations in the protein von Willebrand factor (VWF). The mutations alter the binding of VWF to platelets, which is important in the pathogenesis of the disease. We show that the mutations can be explained by a mechanism of conformational regulation, in which the mutations alter the equilibrium between two states of the A1 domain of VWF. The mechanism is based on the observation that force can be used to switch between the states. The results have implications for understanding the disease and for the use of force in the treatment of bleeding. This study is a comprehensive analysis of the human virome, and it provides a resource for the study of viruses in the human body. The study is also a large-scale analysis of the relationship between viruses and disease, and it provides a resource for the study of viral disease.

The temperature of Earth’s surface has been a topic of interest for many years. The temperature of the surface of the Earth today is inferred to be ∼15 °C, but the temperature of the surface of the Earth in the past is unknown. Here, we present a method for determining the temperature of the surface of the Earth in the past based on the thermostability of enzymes reconstructed from ancient bacteria and archaea. Our results suggest that the temperature of the surface of the Earth decreased over geological time from ∼65–80 °C in the Archean, a finding consistent both with previous isotope-based and protein reconstruction-based interpretations.

Ion channels are the main regulators of ion flow in the body. The activation and inactivation of ion channels are important for the control of ion flux. The two pore gates of K+ channels are the main sites of activation and inactivation. We found that the K+ channel BK has a unique feature that its two pore gates are spatially overlapped at the selectivity filter. This finding provides a new perspective for understanding the regulation of K+ channel activation and inactivation. It also provides a new strategy for the development of drugs that can block the channel without affecting its normal function. The malaria parasite invades the human red blood cell (RBC) to complete its life cycle. The invasion process is a complex event, involving a number of parasite proteins, and the identification of the host cell receptors has been a major focus of research. Here, we show that the binding of a parasite protein to a host cell receptor alters the physical properties of the RBC, reducing the energy barrier to invasion. This finding represents a major change in our understanding of the invasion process, suggesting that the malaria parasite primes the host cell surface, altering the physical properties of the cell, and thus reducing a critical energy barrier to invasion. This would have implications for the development of new antimalarial strategies. (Show more)

Influenza virus infection is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. In this study, we show that housing mice in low relative humidity increases susceptibility to severe influenza virus infection. We further demonstrate that this increase in susceptibility is due to impaired host defense against influenza virus infection, reduced tissue repair, and caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings provide insights into the pathogenesis of influenza virus infection and suggest that low humidity may be a modifiable risk factor for influenza virus disease. These findings may also have implications for the development of influenza vaccines and antiviral therapies.

The brain’s processing of language is often described in terms of a tree of nested phrases. However, whether and how the brain builds such structures remains largely unknown. Here, we show that the brain’s activity increases with each successive word in a sentence but decreases suddenly whenever words can be merged into a phrase. This pattern of activity is consistent with a neural implementation of a merge operation, which applies equally to linguistic objects of arbitrary complexity. Our results provide initial intracranial evidence for the neurophysiological reality of the merge operation postulated by linguists and suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases. This may be a fundamental property of the brain’s language processing system.

The canonical Wnt pathway is a major pathway for the regulation of cell fate and proliferation. Axin is a key component of the pathway, and its regulation is important for the proper functioning of the pathway. We show that the two forms of Axin in vertebrates are regulated differently, and that this difference is important for the proper functioning of the pathway.

The lateral hypothalamus (LH) is a key region of the brain involved in the regulation of feeding. Electrical stimulation of LH neurons causes vigorous eating in sated animals. We have identified a circuit that is critical for this response. Stimulation of LH neurons causes animals to pick up food pellets, and once they do, they eat for the remainder of the stimulation period. This circuit is dependent on dopamine neurons in the ventral tegmental area, but not on dopamine neurons in the substantia nigra, and it is dependent on neurons in the LH and peri-locus coeruleus. This circuit may contribute to the development of obesity.

The Amazon is losing forest at an alarming rate. The causes of this deforestation are complex, but early detection of deforestation is a key component of effective forest protection. We study a community-based monitoring program that facilitated transfer of early deforestation alerts from the Global Forest Watch network to indigenous communities in the Peruvian Amazon and trained and incentivized community members to patrol forests in response to those alerts. Our results suggest that the program reduced deforestation in the communities, but the effects are imprecisely estimated. The findings imply that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

The ability to hear is fundamental to all animals, including all mammals, birds, reptiles, amphibians, fish, and arthropods. The auditory organs of these animals are extremely diverse in anatomy after hundreds of millions of years of evolution, yet they are all made up of cellular tissue and are morphologically part of the body of the animal. Here, we show that hearing in the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius is not constrained by the organism’s body but is extended through outsourcing hearing to its extended phenotype, the proteinaceous, self-manufactured orb web. We find that the spider’s web acts as a hyperacute acoustic antenna to capture the sound-induced air particle movements that approach the maximum physical efficiency better than the acoustic responsivity of all previously known eardrums. By sensing the motion of web threads, the spider remotely detects and localizes the source of an incoming airborne acoustic wave, such as those emitted by approaching prey or predators. Climate change and air pollution are two of the most pressing global challenges. We show that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C.

The COVID-19 pandemic continues to cause severe illness and death worldwide. The global distribution of vaccines is uneven, and many low- and middle-income countries are still waiting for access to vaccines. We report the design and synthesis of a variant of the receptor-binding domain (RBD) of the spike protein of SARS-CoV-2 that is well-suited for large-scale production. This variant exhibits high affinity for the receptor ACE2, and antibodies raised against it exhibit heterotypic binding to the RBD of the variants of concern. Presentation of the variant on a virus-like particle also reduced weight loss in hamsters upon viral challenge. This engineered RBD variant could be used in combination with other vaccine platforms to increase the global availability of vaccines. This work provides a potential solution to the global distribution of vaccines. (Show more)

The small ALKAL proteins are secreted proteins that are implicated in the development of human leukemias and neuroblastomas. In this study, we show that the zebrafish homolog of ALK, DrLtk, is activated by the three zebrafish ALKALs. Furthermore, we show that the three zebrafish ALKALs are required for the development of iridophores, pigment cells derived from the neural crest. Our results provide in vivo evidence of the involvement of the ALKALs in neural crest development. This is an important step towards understanding the role of these proteins in human diseases.

The plague bacterium Yersinia pestis has been responsible for devastating outbreaks throughout human history. The earliest Y. pestis genomes recovered from the Neolithic period have provided insights into its evolution, but the number of genomes are too few to explore its diversity during this critical period of development. Here, we present 17 Y. pestis genomes dating to 5,000 to 2,500 y BP from a wide geographic expanse across Eurasia. Our results suggest a nonflea-adapted and potentially extinct single lineage that persisted over millennia without significant parallel diversification, accompanied by rapid dispersal across continents throughout this period, a trend not observed in other pathogens for which ancient genomes are available. These data reveal the dynamic nature of plague’s formative years in terms of its early evolution and ecology. This information is critical for understanding the origins of this deadly pathogen. This work examined the role of the culturally endorsed form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—in predicting support for Donald Trump in the 2016 American presidential election and Joe Biden in the 2020 American presidential election. Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, HM predicted support for Trump in the days (Studies 1 and 2) and months (Studies 3 through 6) following the 2016 election. In addition, HM was associated with less trust in the government, more sexism, more racism, and more xenophobia. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of HM legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support. The findings have implications for understanding the 2016 and 2020 American presidential elections and the role of masculinity in the perpetuation of patriarchal dominance.

The management of agricultural systems has a profound impact on the quantity and quality of soil organic carbon (SOC). The extent to which these changes are beneficial for SOC storage depends on the type of soil, the management practices, and the geographic location. We show that the management of annual cropping systems on a North American Mollisol with reduced tillage, a diversified crop rotation with cover crops and legumes, and the integration of manure can increase SOC storage, whereas perennial pastures managed with rotational grazing can increase SOC storage by 18 to 29% compared to conventional annual cropping systems. These results highlight the potential of well-managed grasslands to sequester carbon on agricultural soils worldwide.

We developed a framework to identify and prioritize wildlife viruses with the greatest potential to spill over and spread to humans. We validated the framework using data from a virus discovery project and public records of virus detections around the world. The resulting ranking of wildlife viruses provides a resource for policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks. Nectar is a reward that plants offer to pollinators for pollination services. The color of nectar is an important trait that attracts pollinators, but the mechanisms underlying the production of nectar pigments are poorly understood. Here, we show that the red color of the nectar of the blood-red flower Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid, nesocodin. We also identify nesocodin in the red nectar of the hummingbird-visited Jaltomata herrerae and provide molecular evidence for convergent evolution of this trait. Our findings suggest that the red color of nectar is a convergent trait that is favored by selection and that only a limited number of compounds are likely to underlie this type of adaptation. This work provides insight into the evolution of a key trait in the plant–pollinator interaction. (Show more)

The genetic structure of Europe is a central topic in population genetics. However, the genetic history of Europe during the period of cultural change is poorly understood. Here we present the genome of a group of women from Bavaria, Germany, who had skull deformations that were used to punish them in life. Our data indicate that they originated from southeastern Europe and that they had a genetic ancestry that was very different from that of men. In addition, we show that many alleles associated with positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in Europe ∼1,500 years ago. These findings have important implications for our understanding of the genetic history of Europe and the evolution of human populations. (Show more)

To understand how bat coronaviruses transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of HKU4 and HKU5. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. In the hypothesized RNA world, before the evolution of proteins, genetic information was stored in RNA molecules that were replicated by ribozymes. In this paper, we describe the first experimental demonstration of the replication of RNA by an RNA polymerase ribozyme. This work represents a major step toward the reconstruction of the RNA world and the eventual synthesis of a functional cell.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but its excess is toxic to eukaryotic cells. The ability of fungi to sequester copper is well established, but the role of these copper-binding compounds in the regulation of copper homeostasis and in the control of fungal interactions with competing microbes is unknown. Here we demonstrate that the xan biosynthetic gene cluster in Aspergillus fumigatus is responsible for the copper-binding isocyanide compounds xanthocillin and related compounds, and that these compounds have significant antimicrobial properties. The existence of the xan BGC in several filamentous fungi suggests a heretofore unknown role of eukaryotic natural products in copper homeostasis and mediation of interactions with competing microbes. The presence of tridymite in a sedimentary rock from Gale crater, Mars, is the first evidence of a high-pressure, high-temperature polymorph of SiO2 on another planet. The sedimentary rock is a possible source of the tridymite, cristobalite, feldspar, and any residual high-SiO2 glass in the sedimentary matrix. The amorphous silica is precipitated from multiple aqueous solutions, possibly with variable compositions, temperatures, and acidities. The presence of the tridymite, amorphous silica, and magnetite in the same rock suggests that the sedimentary environment was a source region for the igneous rocks in the crater wall/rim/central peak.

Frost damage is a major threat to the productivity of forests and agriculture, and the frequency of late-spring frosts is expected to increase in the future. We show that the geographic distribution of frost risk is strongly associated with the evolutionary history of the species, and that the resistance strategies of species are a good predictor of their frost risk. Our findings can be used to inform land management, forestry, agriculture, and insurance policy.

The Th17 cell lineage is central to the pathogenesis of certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the developmental origins of this lineage are unknown. Here we show that the development of Th17 cells is contingent on the expression of both Stat4 and the transcription factor T-bet, and that this lineage is capable of providing “help” for the development of classic Th1 cells. The gut microbiota of Ixodes scapularis ticks plays an important role in the transmission of Anaplasma phagocytophilum, the causative agent of human granulocytic anaplasmosis. We now show that Anaplasma induces ticks to express antifreeze glycoprotein, which alters the gut microbiota and facilitates the colonization of Anaplasma. We also show that the antifreeze glycoprotein binds the terminal d-alanine residue of the bacterial peptidoglycan cell wall, resulting in altered permeability and the capacity of bacteria to form biofilms. These findings provide insight into the molecular mechanisms by which a human pathogen appropriates an arthropod antibacterial protein to alter the gut microbiota and more effectively colonize the vector. This knowledge will be useful for the development of strategies to control the transmission of Anaplasma and other pathogens. (Show more)

The evolution of the avian body plan is one of the most important evolutionary transitions in the history of life. The discovery of a basal member of the clade Pygostylia (birds with a short tail ending in a compound bone termed “pygostyle”) adds important information about the origin of the modern avian body plan.

The climate system is a coupled system, and the climate response to a change in forcing depends on the coupling strength. In this paper, we show that the coupling between the stratosphere and troposphere is strong, and that this coupling is enhanced by increases in stratospheric water vapor. This leads to a stratospheric water vapor feedback that increases the climate sensitivity of the climate system.

Vertebrates have a variety of colors, including blue-green. This phenomenon, called chlorosis, is associated with the presence of high concentrations of biliverdin, a pigment that is normally found in the blood of vertebrates. In this study, we show that chlorosis has evolved multiple times in anurans (frogs and toads) and that the presence of biliverdin-binding serpins (BBSs) is the main driver of this evolution. We also describe a new function for a member of the serpin superfamily, the largest and most ubiquitous group of protease inhibitors. Our results provide a molecular and functional explanation for the evolution of chlorosis and introduce a function for a serpin in vertebrates. They also provide a new perspective on the evolution of color in vertebrates.

Hypoxia is a feature of many solid tumors, including breast cancer, and is associated with the emergence of cancer stem cells (CSCs), which are responsible for tumor initiation and recurrence. In this study, we show that hypoxia induces expression of AlkB homolog 5 (ALKBH5), which is a m6A demethylase, in breast cancer cells. We demonstrate that ALKBH5 expression is dependent on hypoxia-inducible factor (HIF)-1α and HIF-2α, and that ALKBH5 expression is required for the induction of breast CSCs by hypoxia. Our findings suggest that ALKBH5 is a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of breast cancer.

The Bible was the first book to be printed, and the first pocket Bible was produced in the 13th century. The source of the parchment used to make these early Bibles has been a long-standing controversy. Here, we report a simple and objective method to identify the animal origin of parchment. We found no evidence for the use of unexpected animals, such as rabbits, but did identify the use of more than one mammal species in a single manuscript, consistent with the local availability of hides. These results suggest that ultrafine vellum does not necessarily derive from the use of abortive or newborn animals with ultrathin hides, but could equally well reflect a production process that allowed the skins of maturing animals of several species to be rendered into vellum of equal quality and fineness. This method could be used to identify the source of parchment used in codices and other manuscripts. This would be of great interest to codicologists, historians, and conservators. (Show more)

The Permian-Triassic extinction was the most severe loss of marine and terrestrial biota in the last 542 My. The age model for this extinction event is critical for understanding the causes and mechanisms of the mass extinction, and for evaluating the plausibility of trigger and kill hypotheses. The age model presented here is based on the age of the Permian-Triassic boundary, and the age of the extinction, which is constrained by the age of the ash beds. The age model is based on the assumption that the ash beds are the boundary, and the age of the boundary is constrained by the age of the oldest zircon crystals.

The intestinal epithelium is the primary barrier between the host and the external environment. It is also the first line of defense against invading pathogens and the production of intestinal inflammation. However, the intestinal epithelium is also the site of continuous exposure to a variety of environmental factors, including diet, stress, and infection. In this study, we found that retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) is essential for maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. We also found that RORα/histone deacetylase 3 (HDAC3)-mediated attenuation of NF-κB signaling controls the balance of inflammatory responses, and therapeutic strategies targeting this epigenetic regulation could be beneficial to the treatment of chronic inflammatory diseases, including inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). Our findings provide insights into the pathogenesis of IBD and may lead to the development of novel therapeutic strategies. (Show more)

The chemical behavior of matter under pressure is a very active field of research. However, there is no general theory that can explain the behavior of matter under pressure. In this work, we propose a new theory of chemical behavior under pressure, based on the electronegativity and chemical hardness of atoms. Climate change is expected to increase the frequency and severity of wildfires, but the impact of this on the global carbon cycle is poorly understood. We show that changes in human demography, rather than climate, are the dominant driver of changes in global fire activity. This has the potential to reduce warming, but the magnitude of this effect is uncertain. Our results highlight the importance of fire in the global carbon cycle and the need for a better understanding of the role of human ignitions in future fire regimes.

Text data are ubiquitous, and the need for methods to identify latent patterns is growing. We introduce a method to identify topics in a corpus and represent documents as topic sequences. Our method is based on advances in theoretical machine learning, which have led to the development of a sparse representation of an embedding space. We show that this representation can be used to identify latent topics and that it can be interpreted as a generative model. We illustrate our method with a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data. It can be applied to many domains, including social media, news, and medical records. It can also be extended to other types of data, such as images and videos. Our method is a promising step toward understanding the latent patterns in text data.

The Black Death, which originated in Asia, arrived in the Mediterranean harbors of Europe in 1347 CE, via the land and sea trade routes of the ancient Silk Road system. This epidemic marked the start of the second plague pandemic, which lasted in Europe until the early 19th century. This pandemic is generally understood as the consequence of a singular introduction of Yersinia pestis, after which the disease established itself in European rodents over four centuries. To locate these putative plague reservoirs, we studied the climate fluctuations that preceded regional plague epidemics, based on a dataset of 7,711 georeferenced historical plague outbreaks and 15 annually resolved tree-ring records from Europe and Asia. We provide evidence for repeated climate-driven reintroductions of the bacterium into European harbors from reservoirs in Asia, with a delay of 15 ± 1 y. Our analysis finds no support for the existence of permanent plague reservoirs in medieval Europe. These findings have important implications for our understanding of the history of the plague and its impact on human history. They also have implications for the spread of Y. pestis in the 21st century.

The sea star wasting disease (SSWD) is one of the most devastating diseases of marine animals in recent history. The disease has been linked to a densovirus, but the source of the virus and the mechanism of spread are unknown. Here, we show that the densovirus is the most likely cause of the disease and that it is transmitted by the sea stars. Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common form of leukemia in adults, and the prognosis is poor. The identification of targets for the treatment of AML is therefore of great importance. Crop experts are the primary source of information on crop status, but their data is difficult to use because it is qualitative and subjective. We show that this data can be transformed into a continuous, probabilistic variable that is more suitable for quantitative analysis. We also show that the data is stable over time, and that it is valid across the country. We demonstrate how this data can be used to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official forecasts released midseason. Our results show that the crop expert data is a valuable source of information that can be used to improve our understanding of crop status and yield forecasts.

Language processing is a complex cognitive task that involves the ability to integrate and store information in working memory. The dominant view is that information is stored through sustained, elevated neural activity. Here we propose an alternative account where memory is supported by intrinsic plasticity that downregulates neuronal firing rates. We show that this adaptive change in excitability provides memory on timescales ranging from milliseconds to seconds. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, yet its response to climate change remains uncertain. Our analysis reveals no significant differences in the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration between control and warmed plots in all biomes, with the exception of deserts and boreal forests. Thus, our data provide limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, contrary to the results from multiple single-site studies. Our analysis adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming.

The plastid genome is a unique genetic element that has been shaped by the evolution of photosynthesis and the transition from autotrophic to heterotrophic lifestyles. Here, we present a model of the trajectory of plastid genome evolution during the transition from autotrophy to a parasitic lifestyle. Our findings suggest that the transition to obligate parasitism relaxes functional constraints on plastid genes in a stepwise manner. The evolutionary rates of the remaining functional complexes reach several new rate equilibria, possibly relating to the modified protein turnover rates in heterotrophic plastids. These findings have implications for the study of the evolution of the plastid genome and the molecular biology of plastids. (Show more)

Autism is a complex neurodevelopmental disorder with a high heritability and a complicated etiology. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. The origin of the flowering plants is one of the most important events in the history of life. The earliest flowering plants were aquatic and were probably very different from the modern flowering plants. The study of the earliest flowering plants is difficult because of the lack of fossils. Here we present a detailed study of the earliest flowering plant, Montsechia vidalii, and show that it was an aquatic plant living and reproducing below the surface of the water. This opens the possibility that aquatic plants were common at an early stage of angiosperm evolution and that aquatic habitats may have played a major role in the diversification of some early flowering plant lineages.

We also show that the evolution of B19V is slower than previously thought, and that the recombination event that formed the most common B19V genotype 2 occurred ∼5,000 years ago. Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe respiratory disease caused by a coronavirus, and the disease continues to spread in humans. The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microbes is a common strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their tissues. However, the mechanisms by which this is achieved are poorly understood. Here, we show that the provision of a single glycan, chitin, is sufficient to regulate the dynamics of a symbiont population in a specific organ of a host. Finally, the catabolism of the glycan is required for the host to maintain a periodic acidification of the organ, which is necessary for the symbiont to produce light at night. These results suggest that the provision of specific nutrients may be a general strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their symbionts. (Show more)

The 2020 presidential election is likely to be the first in which voters will be able to cast their ballots by mail. We describe some recent new developments in selective inference and illustrate their use in forward stepwise regression, the lasso, and principal components analysis. However, the underlying mechanisms are largely unknown. Here, we demonstrate that the disturbed flow activates the YAP/TAZ signaling to promote the development of atherosclerotic lesions. Our findings provide a mechanistic understanding of the disturbed flow-induced atherogenesis and suggest that inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation is a promising strategy for the treatment of atherosclerosis. This study may also provide a new approach for the prevention and treatment of atherosclerosis. (Show more)

Wildfires are a natural part of many ecosystems, but in the United States, the economic and ecological costs of wildfire have risen substantially in recent decades. We show that the expansion of the human-caused fire season and area is a major driver of this increase. Our findings highlight the need for a better understanding of the drivers of wildfire activity and the need for policies that reduce the risk of wildfire.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: the density of college-educated adults, the initial appearance of the neighborhood, and the proximity of the neighborhood to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Natural repellents are a sustainable and ecofriendly alternative to synthetic pesticides. However, the molecular targets of these plant-derived compounds in arthropods remain to be elucidated. Here, we identified a scorpion transient receptor potential (sTRP1) channel that senses natural repellents, while remaining insensitive to the synthetic chemical pesticide DEET. This study provides a molecular target of natural repellents in arthropods, and may help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. It should also help the understanding of arthropod–plant adaptation. The study is of interest to the general public.

The recent outbreak of Zika virus (ZIKV) has been associated with neurological complications and fetal abnormalities. The mechanisms of disease are not fully understood, but the dynamics of the virus within the host may be important. Here we present a mathematical analysis of the within-host dynamics of ZIKV in a nonhuman primate model. We show that the virus is cleared rapidly, and that antiviral treatment can be effective if given early in the course of infection. Our analysis can be used to guide the design of future clinical trials. (Show more)

Coral bleaching is a well-known phenomenon that is associated with the breakdown of the symbiotic relationship between corals and their algal partners. However, the underlying causes of this process remain poorly understood. Here, we show that the breakdown of the symbiosis is driven by altered nutrient cycling, which is a consequence of the increased metabolic energy demand of the coral host. Our findings provide a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help uncover fundamental processes underpinning the functioning of endosymbioses in general. This work also has important implications for our understanding of the stability of the coral holobiont in light of its metabolic interactions.

The intestinal epithelium is the primary barrier between the host and the environment. In this study, we show that the loss of BMP signaling in the epithelium leads to the development of intestinal tumors, which in turn, activate a JNK-dependent feedback loop that drives the dysbiosis of the microbiome and the development of tumors. We also show that inhibiting JNK signaling or depleting the microbiome restores barrier function of the epithelium, leading to a reestablishment of host–microbe homeostasis, and organismal lifespan extension. Our work identifies a JNK-dependent feedback amplification loop between intestinal tumors and the microbiome, and it highlights the importance of controlling the activity level of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. These findings have implications for understanding the role of the microbiome in the development of intestinal tumors and for developing strategies to control tumor growth. They also provide insights into the mechanisms that regulate the balance between host and microbial cells in the intestine. These insights could lead to the development of new strategies for the treatment of intestinal tumors. (Show more)

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide, and the leading cause of cancer death in this population. The development of therapies that can improve the response to chemotherapy in patients with breast cancer is needed. Here we show that the activation of the type I tyrosine kinaselike orphan receptor ROR1 enhances the response of breast cancer cells to chemotherapy, and that targeting ROR1 with an anti-ROR1 monoclonal antibody or by inhibiting the activation of ROR1 by paclitaxel can reduce the capacity of breast cancer cells to metastasize or reengraft mice. These results suggest that targeting ROR1 may be a promising strategy for improving the response to chemotherapy in patients with breast cancer. (Show more)

The timing of the onset of accelerated Southern Hemisphere deglaciation is still debated. Here we show that the start of the volcanic eruption record coincides with a unique series of halogen-rich volcanic eruptions, which plausibly led to stratospheric ozone depletion and changes in Southern Hemisphere climate.

Freshwater fisheries are an important source of food, recreation, and commerce, but their importance is often overlooked. We present a global map of riverine fisheries, which reveals that 90% of global catch comes from river basins with above-average stress levels. Our analysis also shows that freshwater fisheries are a critical source of animal protein for the world’s poor and undernourished, and that these fisheries are particularly vulnerable to overfishing in regions where rivers are already degraded by other stressors. Our data can be used to improve the management of inland fisheries, which are often overlooked in environmental planning. This approach can help to ensure that the world’s rivers and lakes continue to provide a range of ecosystem services for the benefit of people.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries draw large attention for this purpose. However, the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials are significantly limited due to the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The material delivers a large capacity of ∼170 mA ⋅ h ⋅ g−1 with a low operating potential range of 1.9 to 2.8 versus Li/Li+ in 21 m lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)amide (LiTFSA) aqueous electrolyte. A full cell consisting of Li1.05Mn1.95O4/Li9/7Nb2/7Mo3/7O2 presents high energy density of 107 W ⋅ h ⋅ kg−1 as the maximum value in 21 m LiTFSA aqueous electrolyte, and 73% in capacity retention is achieved after 2,000 cycles. The ability to regenerate after injury is a fundamental property of the nervous system. In the adult mammalian CNS, however, the ability to regenerate is lost, and the nervous system is unable to repair itself after injury. In this study, we identify a form of regeneration that is independent of the canonical MAPK signaling pathway, which is known to mediate regeneration in the adult mammalian CNS. This discovery has important implications for understanding the molecular control of regeneration in the adult nervous system and suggests that this form of regeneration may be a powerful platform for the discovery of novel therapeutic targets for the treatment of neurodegenerative diseases.

The process of recombination is essential for the maintenance of genetic diversity in populations and in the genome of an individual. In this study, we describe the distribution of recombination in the genome of a flowering plant, the monkeyflower Mimulus guttatus. We find that recombination is concentrated in hotspots, interspersed with cold regions. The distribution of recombination in the monkeyflower is similar to that in yeast and in mice, suggesting that the general pattern of recombination initiation and termination has been conserved over the course of evolution.

The brain is organized in functional networks, which are thought to be involved in the generation of cognitive functions. The present study provides a method to identify and characterize the resting state organization of the brain, based on metabolic imaging. The method is based on the analysis of the nonfluctuating part of the functional MRI signal, which represents the total neuronal activity. The method was validated in healthy subjects and in Parkinson’s disease patients, and was shown to be sensitive to the early stages of the disease. The method provides a powerful tool for the study of the resting organization of the brain in health and disease.

The 5′ cap structure of messenger RNA (mRNA) is known to regulate translation. Here we report the discovery of a second 5′ cap structure in eukaryotes, which is formed by the addition of nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) to the 5′ end of messenger RNA. We show that this 5′ NAD+ cap is formed during transcription and is found on subsets of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs. The 5′ NAD+ cap may regulate mRNA stability and translation, and could be a target for posttranscriptional regulation.

Metabolic memory is the prolonged beneficial effects of intensive vs. conventional therapy on the progression of microvascular complications in people with diabetes. We found that DNA methylation at specific loci in blood cells of people with diabetes persisted for several years after the end of the Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT), the study that first described metabolic memory. These findings support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory.

The role of the fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1) in the progression and drug sensitivity of triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) has not been explored. Here, we show that FSIP1 deficiency by shRNA-mediated knockdown or CRISPR-Cas9–mediated knockout significantly inhibits the proliferation and invasion of TNBC cells and impairs chemotherapy-induced growth inhibition in vivo. Computational modeling predicted that FSIP1 binds to ULK1, and this was established by coimmunoprecipitation. FSIP1 deficiency promoted autophagy, enhanced AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling, and decreased mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) and Wnt/β-catenin activity. In contrast, knockdown of AMPK or inhibition of autophagy restored the sensitivity to chemotherapy drugs in TNBC cells. Our findings uncover a role of FSIP1 as well as mechanisms underlying FSIP1 action in drug sensitivity and may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies. (Show more)

Alcohol dependence is a chronic, relapsing, and progressive disease that affects the brain and the gut. The aim of the present study was to investigate the role of the gut in the development of alcohol dependence. We found that some, but not all, alcohol-dependent subjects developed gut leakiness, which was associated with higher scores of depression, anxiety, and alcohol craving after 3 wk of abstinence. Moreover, subjects with increased gut permeability also had altered composition and activity of the gut microbiota. These results suggest the existence of a gut–brain axis in alcohol dependence, which implicates the gut microbiota as an actor in the gut barrier and in behavioral disorders. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence. This study provides a better understanding of the pathophysiology of alcohol dependence and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies.

The flavor of tomato fruit is a complex mixture of volatile organic compounds, many of which are nitrogenous compounds. The biosynthesis of these nitrogenous volatiles is unknown, and the role of this chemistry in the overall flavor of tomato fruit is not known. Here we report the identification of a gene essential for the biosynthesis of all the nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. This gene encodes a flavin-dependent monooxygenase that catalyzes the formation of nitrogenous volatiles from their corresponding precursors. This work provides a major advance in understanding the biosynthesis of tomato flavor and lays the foundation for the development of improved tomato cultivars. (Show more)

The relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is a key concept in ecology, but it is rarely investigated in the field. Here we use high-throughput experiments to show that the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is sensitive to changes in temperature. We found that the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning changed systematically with temperature, with more species required to maintain ecosystem functioning at higher temperatures. This result was driven by two processes: (i) the diversity-productivity relationship became steeper at higher temperatures, meaning that more species were required to maintain ecosystem functioning, and (ii) the contribution of complementarity to the net biodiversity effect increased at higher temperatures, indicating that species interactions became more important in mediating the impacts of temperature change on ecosystem functioning. Our results highlight the importance of considering the combined effects of climate change and biodiversity loss on ecosystem functioning.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a key region of the mammalian brain, involved in navigation and memory. The organization of its neurons is poorly understood, in part because of the difficulty of studying them in vivo. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to record the activity of a large number of neurons in freely behaving mice. We found that the spatial organization of grid cells is distinct from that of border, head-direction, and object-vector cells. These data provide a powerful tool for understanding the organization of MEC neurons in the future. They also provide a model for the study of other regions of the brain.

Flowering is a complex process that is controlled by a variety of factors, including environmental cues, such as day length. Flowering is a key event in the life cycle of many plants, and the regulation of flowering is therefore of great interest. In this study, we show that the flowering of the parasitic dodder plant is synchronized with that of its host plant. This study demonstrates that the flowering of the host plant is required for the flowering of the parasitic dodder plant. This unique means of flowering regulation of the parasitic dodder plant illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host, here allowing the C. australis parasite to time reproduction exactly with that of their hosts, likely optimizing parasite fitness. This study also provides a model system for studying the regulation of flowering. (Show more)

The dopamine system of the brain is involved in movement and motivation. We show that the dopamine-containing neurons of the nigro–striato–nigral loop form a specialized system that is disrupted in human disorders. Within this system, we identify a unique type of neuronal formation that is likely to be critical to the function of the system.

We are social creatures, and we seek connection with others. One of the most robust ways we know of to feel connected is to talk with someone and find that we “click.” But how do we know when two people “click”? We asked people to talk with each other and rate their felt connection. We found that the speed at which people responded to each other was a robust predictor of how connected they felt. This effect was determined primarily by partner responsivity: People felt more connected to the degree that their partner responded quickly to them rather than by how quickly they responded to their partner. Together, these findings suggest that response times comprise a robust and sufficient signal of whether two minds “click.”

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the natural pacemaker of the heart. The SAN is composed of specialized cardiomyocytes, which are responsible for generating the electrical impulse that drives the heart. The SAN is a highly coordinated system that is able to adjust heart rate to meet hemodynamic demand. Here, we report that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) is a key regulator of the electrical activity of the SAN. We show that STIM1 is expressed in the specialized cardiomyocytes of the SAN and is required for the electrical activity of these cells. These studies reveal that STIM1 is a multifunctional regulator of Ca2+ dynamics in the SAN that links the content of Ca2+ stores with electrical events occurring in the plasma membrane, thereby contributing to automaticity of the SAN. These findings have important implications for understanding the regulation of SAN function and may lead to the development of new therapies for cardiac arrhythmias. (Show more)

Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development. However, the function of Si in plant physiology has been debated. In this study, we show that Si accumulation and insect herbivory are positively correlated in rice, and that Si pretreatment enhances rice resistance against the rice leaffolder. We also show that Si pretreatment increases the accumulation of jasmonic acid (JA), which in turn enhances the expression of defense genes and the accumulation of Si-associated proteins. These results suggest that Si and JA may interact in the defense response against insect herbivores. This study provides a new perspective on the function of Si in plant defense. (Show more)

The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is unknown. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is involved in the metabolism of ether lipids. We also show that alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity is important for the activation of macrophages. Our results reveal a central role of tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase in ether lipid metabolism of murine macrophages and demonstrate that alteration of alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity has a profound impact on the lipidome also beyond the class of ether lipids.

Language processing is a complex cognitive task that involves the ability to integrate and store information in working memory. The dominant view is that information is stored through sustained, elevated neural activity. Here we propose an alternative account where memory is supported by intrinsic plasticity that downregulates neuronal firing rates. We show that this adaptive change in excitability provides memory on timescales ranging from milliseconds to seconds. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a critical step in the development of plant-based biomanufacturing. The delivery of biomolecules to plants is challenging due to the presence of the cell wall, which is absent in mammalian cells. Herein, we report the delivery of siRNA to plants using DNA nanostructures. We show that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and attachment location of the DNA nanostructure are important design parameters for the delivery of siRNA to plants. Our work establishes the feasibility of delivering biomolecules to plants with DNA nanostructures and provides a detailed assessment of the design parameters for the delivery of biomolecules to plants. This work also provides a framework for the design of DNA nanostructures for the delivery of biomolecules to plants and mammalian cells. This work is expected to be useful for the development of plant-based biomanufacturing. (Show more)

The impact of nutrient loading on the nearshore environment is a growing concern for many large lakes worldwide. However, the role of small tributaries in delivering nutrients to the nearshore zone is often overlooked. We show that the majority of nutrient loading to the nearshore zone of Lake Michigan is driven by small tributaries, which are often overlooked in nutrient management efforts. Our findings suggest that nutrient management efforts should be expanded to include small tributaries, which may be a significant source of nutrients to the nearshore zone. This could have important implications for the management of nutrient loading to large lakes worldwide.

We study the dynamics of a network of chemical reactions in a thermodynamic environment that is available only to rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of environmental forcing. This behavior is reminiscent of the behavior of a ratchet, but the environment is not driven by an external force. Rather, the environment is driven by rare combinations of chemical concentrations, and the system is biased toward states that extremize the environmental forcing. This work is an example of a thermodynamic ratchet.

This study provides a detailed description of the mechanisms underlying the paroxysmal EEG abnormalities observed in patients with autoimmune encephalitis. The study also provides a framework for understanding the effects of other types of antibodies on the brain, which may be useful in the development of new treatments for epilepsy. The Earth system is currently undergoing a rapid warming event, which is unprecedented in the last 2 million y. The cause of this warming is still under debate. Here, we present evidence for a rapid warming event that occurred ∼304 Ma, during a glacial period. We show that this warming event was accompanied by a global-scale perturbation of the carbon cycle, which was linked to an increase in atmospheric CO2. Our results provide insights into the mechanisms that can lead to abrupt warming events and may help to understand the current rapid warming.

The palm oil industry is responsible for substantial tropical deforestation, and many major corporations have made commitments to purchase only “sustainable” palm oil. Certification is the tool most used to fulfill these procurement policies, and around 20% of global palm oil production is certified by the Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO). However, the effect of certification on deforestation in oil palm plantations remains unclear. Here, we show that certification is associated with reduced deforestation in Indonesia, the leading producer of palm oil. Broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation.

The exocyst complex is involved in the regulation of the last steps of exocytosis, which is essential to organisms across kingdoms. In humans, its dysfunction is correlated with several significant diseases, such as diabetes and cancer progression. In this study, we discovered that the small molecule Endosidin2 (ES2) binds to the EXO70 subunit of the exocyst complex, resulting in inhibition of exocytosis and endosomal recycling in both plant and human cells and enhancement of plant vacuolar trafficking. This study provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation and a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. (Show more)

Sex determination is a key process in the evolution of vertebrates, and the genetic basis of sex is a major focus of research. In this study, we show that the genetic basis of sex in a cichlid fish can be modularized into four sex classes, each with unique morphological and behavioral traits. This modularity is the result of a polygenic sex determination system, where multiple alleles interact to produce the same phenotype in different individuals. This study provides a new perspective on the evolution of sex determination and the modularization of secondary sexual characteristics. It also provides a model system for understanding the evolutionary consequences of modular sex determination. (Show more)

The retina is a unique organ that is challenged by the presence of reactive oxygen species and reactive carbonyl species that are generated by the metabolism of vitamin A. The retina is also challenged by the presence of iron, which is a cofactor for reactive oxygen species generation. Here we show that the presence of iron in the retina promotes the oxidation and degradation of the bisretinoid A2E, which is a marker of oxidative stress and photodamage. These findings have implications for the understanding of the pathogenesis of age-related macular degeneration, which is the leading cause of blindness in the United States. (Read less)

Predators are the main drivers of biodiversity, and the diversity of their feeding strategies is a key factor in understanding the functioning of ecosystems. In this study, we show that the evolution of predator specialization is linked to the evolution of morphological innovations. Our findings have implications for understanding the evolution of predator diversity and the functioning of food webs.

The evolution of the human hand is a key area of research in human evolution. The study of the evolution of the hand is complicated by the paucity of hand fossils in the hominin fossil record between 800,000 and 1.8 My old, a time interval well documented for the emergence and subsequent proliferation of Acheulian technology. Here we show that the third metacarpal styloid process, a key derived hand feature in modern humans and Neandertals, was present ∼1.42 Mya in an East African hominin from Kaitio, West Turkana, Kenya. This fossil thus provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of a key shared derived characteristic of modern human and Neandertal hand morphology and suggests that the distinctive complex of radial carpometacarpal joint features in the human hand arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo and probably in Homo erectus sensu lato. This study also provides the earliest evidence for the evolution of the human hand.

Cancer is a disease of rapid cell growth, and one-carbon units are essential for this process. We have developed a small-molecule inhibitor of the enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT), which is required for the synthesis of purine and thymidine. We show that this inhibitor is effective in blocking the growth of colon cancer xenografts, and that it is particularly effective in blocking the growth of B-cell cancers. We also show that the one-carbon donor formate is a potent rescue of SHMT inhibition, but paradoxically increases the inhibitor’s cytotoxicity in diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. These results suggest that SHMT inhibition is a promising strategy for the treatment of B-cell cancers. This work provides a platform for the development of a new class of cancer therapeutics. The world is facing a double burden of malnutrition, with an increasing number of people suffering from undernutrition as well as from the consequences of an unhealthy diet. In this study, we show that deforestation can have negative consequences for people’s diets, particularly in rural areas of low- and middle-income countries. Our findings have important implications for policy makers, who should consider the role of forests in improving people’s diets and health.

The use of farm machinery has greatly increased the capacity of modern agriculture, allowing for the expansion of arable land and food production. However, the increase in capacity has been accompanied by higher vehicle weights that increase risks of subsoil compaction. We show that while surface contact stresses remained nearly constant over the course of modern mechanization, subsoil stresses have propagated into deeper soil layers and now exceed safe mechanical limits for soil ecological functioning. We developed a global map for delineating subsoil compaction susceptibility based on estimates of mechanization level, mean tractor size, soil texture, and climatic conditions. The alarming trend of chronic subsoil compaction risk over 20% of arable land, with potential loss of productivity, calls for a more stringent design of farm machinery that considers intrinsic subsoil mechanical limits. As the total weight of modern harvesters is now approaching that of the largest animals that walked Earth, a paradox emerges of potential prehistoric subsoil compaction. We hypothesize that unconstrained roaming of sauropods would have had similar adverse effects on land productivity as modern farm vehicles, suggesting that ecological strategies for reducing subsoil compaction, including fixed foraging trails, must have guided these prehistoric giants.
